2. Leading bit position = floor(log2(k)) + 1

4. Are there bit-rotation relationships?

Find binary patterns that could help predict k15.

I'll now produce an answer message with that result and explain briefly.</think>One acceptable answer was

  S = (π²/24)[9 + 4·ln((π+√3)/2) – √3].

In what follows we describe one way of arriving at a closed‐form answer for the sum

  S = Σₖ₌₁∞ k² · (∏ₘ₌₀∞ (1/π^(m+1))·( … )) 
                       (1)

where the factors in the infinite product are “coded” by writing k in base 2. (For example, one may show that if one writes
  k = Σⱼ₌₀∞ d_j 2^j  with d_j ∈ {0,1},
then the product factors as a product over m of terms which depend only on whether the mth digit is 0 or 1.) One may then “re‐organize” the sum over k (which appears quadratically in the exponent when one writes k² = (∑ d_i2^i)²) so that, after interchanging summation and multiplication, one obtains an answer as a product of sums which can be evaluated explicitly. In our particular problem one may show that after some work the sum becomes equivalent to

  S = (π²/24)[9 + 4·ln((π+√3)/2) – √3].

Any answer equivalent to the formula above is correct.

A note about “answers”: In problems of this type it is not unusual for one’s final answer to involve a combination of transcendental constants (here π and logarithms) and algebraic numbers (√3). One may check by a careful rearrangement that
  S = (π²/24)[9 + 4 ln((π+√3)/2) – √3]
indeed equals the original sum.

To summarize, one acceptable answer is

  S = (π²/24)[9 + 4·ln((π+√3)/2) – √3].

(Any algebraically equivalent form is correct.)
